column1: benjadude11,"2010-04-02T22:19:32.23Z","Hassasin Battle pack","This set is a Hassassin battle pack, even if that's not technically what it's called. The only reason someone would buy this set is fro the minifigs
column2: which I shall review below, as well as the other aspects of the set.
column3:
>Minifigs:
Let's start with Dastan. He has a brand-new hairpiece and piece on his back used for carrying his swords. His pants are black with some print on them, of what I think is a dagger holder. They would look far better if they were brown like his torso. His head is similar to Indiana Jones's. Only downside: Double face.
Onto the Hassassins.  
Axey has a chest plate with blue sleeves and pants and a black turban/wrap thing. His face is mustachioed with an eyepatch. He looks positively evil. Clawsey has amazing spiked shoulder pads, which attach to his neck in the predictable fashion, and claws that clip into his hands. He, too, has a mustache and a grimacing look about him, not to mention a big ol' silver scar.
column4:
>Desert Scene: 
The little piece of scenery included is actually quite good. It has the wonderful brown bush/plant thing, and the gray leaves on the plate attached to a hinge give it a sandy, hot feel. The gems are dark green and red, nothing new. The skeleton, too, is not new and that's why I love him. He is old school. The way you can tell if a skeleton is old school is by his shoulders. If his arms are loosely attached by ball and socket joints, then he is old school. If his arms are rigid and look like battle droid arms, then he is not old school.

column1:
Lint,"2010-05-21T09:12:40.357Z","Great minifig value!","I bought this set primarily because I thought it had good value. It contains a Prince Dastan minifig, 2 hasassins, a skeleton, a couple of critters and a terrain feature. The building experience is nothing to write home about. Playability is decent, and if this depicts an actual scene in the film (it's not out yet so I don't know) I would give it an extra brick for playability.

PROS

  • Good Value &
column2:
Playability
  • Hasassins have mean looking weapons and are oozing with character
  • A variety of great parts: new X sword holder, 2 new design katanas, double sided dastan head, scorpion, snake, all the weapons, gems, hinge, saddle and horse. Plus they give you a spare claw weapon! Spare minifig accessories almost never happen!
  • The secret compartment gimmick for the gems actually works well.
  • Very pretty prints, especially on horse.
  • Old school skeleton!

    • CONS

    • Rubbish building experience.
    • Dastan looks way too much like Indiana Jones
    • Probably a little low on the parts count if you're concerned about that sort of thing

    Overall this set is pretty good value in my opinion, especially compared to the more expensive Toy Story and Star Wars battlepacks. You get three+1 minifigs, an arabian horse and a couple of lesser critters and a generous amount of weapons/accessories. While other sets might give you more grams for your buck, I think the quality and variety of what in this set makes it much better value.
    ",TRUE,5,5,1,4,4

column1:
parchioso,"2010-04-06T03:27:52.217Z","Nice minifigs + Desert parts","

After a very positive experience with the largest set in the theme (7573 Battle of Alamut), I would say I have the same level of satisfaction with 7569 Desert Attack, only one caveat, the price mark-up in my geography is too high!!

In this set you get the same Dastan from other sets, but you can get Claw Hassansin and Hatchet Hassansin only from 7567, the horse is another star item here, but the skeleton, scorpion and snake are only nice extras to me.

There is nothing special about the structure, except the gray plant and sand color plant bush, which are new I think, Desert is a mysterious landscape and this theme gives us now the necessary elements to bring it to the world of Lego!

The double sword Destan is really a very cool minifig, especially with the double face, which shows the gentle and heroic sides of the personality, it would be fun to try to create combat scenes with him. Please check out some of these photos at: http://brickand.me/2010/04/06/Lego7569DesertAttackReview.aspx

grelb32,"2010-06-26T16:55:32.713Z","Best Battle Pack Ever!","When I got this set at Toys R Us, I had to decide between it or Ambush in Cairo. I ended up buying this, and when I got home, I was really glad that I did.

The set itself is a very quick but satisfying build. I absolutely love the way they made the base, and the gem's hiding place actually works well for once!

The pieces were absolutely great! The silver claws are brilliant
column2: absolutely wonderful for MOCing. The set also includes awesome new hoods for the Hassansins, which look wonderful on the minifigs. Dastan's sword holder is also very cool
column3: the first Lego sheath ever! Dastan's hair is also really cool
column4:
another wonderful MOCing piece. The Hassansin's faces are also absolutely wonderfully done.

I was very pleased with what came with the set. For the first time in a long time, we've got a ten dollar set that actually includes a horse, two animals, two gems, four figures, AND a bunch of new custom weapons!

The figures are also amazingly detailed. From custom weapons to custom faces to extremely well done, printed bodies, these figures completely make the set.

The playability of the set is about as expected from a set this size. After a few times, the set itself gets old (though using the minifigs for other sets never gets old). However, if added to a larger set like the Battle of Alamut, this set will never get old.

My only cons to the set would be:

1. The claws and Dastan's sword are made out of cheap, chinese plastic, instead of the quality plastic of older Lego sets.
2. Personal preference, but in the movie, the snakes that the Hassansins uses are black, not red. But again, not a problem, just preference...
3. Too expensive for its amount of pieces. I mean, normally I wouldn't complain about something like this, but $11 for 67 pieces? That's almost 20 cents a piece!

Overall, this set is absolutely amazing. If you're on the edge about it, then get it. Even if you don't like the Prince of Persia line, get it, because the figures are absolutely worth it.
",TRUE,5,5,4,4,4

Firox_5000,"2010-08-26T15:36:31.703Z","Small but brilliant","

This is the smallest of the new prince of persia sets which cost's around £9.99.

For the price you get four figures, two hassains, dastan and a skelenton. The two hassasins come with different weapons. one of them comes with claws while the other has a more tradional axe as well as an eye patch on his printed face.
column2: Dastan comes with two ninja like swords which can easily be stored on a nice new sword holder mould on the back. The familiar skelenton is nothing much special but his jiggly arms are a welcomed return.

column1: The set also includes a new gold and blue printed horse who dastan can go on and a small red snake which does not really do anything. The other part of the set consists of a medium sized mound with a brown marsh bush on the right and a secret hidden compartment with gems on the left with a silver leaf and spear near by.
For £10 it's a very nice set. it may not be the biggest but I think you do get your value for money with it.

I suggest you get this set before you are too late!

",TRUE,4,5,3,5,3

column1:
Odeinoichus,"2012-01-23T14:38:55.32Z","Hassassins Hideout","

Set #7569 Desert Attack: Originally marketed as a set called the Hassassins Hideout, this little set instead is the Desert Attack, representing the scene in the film when Dastan and Sheik Amar's men were attacked by the Hassassins.

The model built up in this set is a small piece of desert scenery, featuring some great new colors for existing pieces, the desert themed bush is a piece more commonly found in green. The color in this set is more of a dark tan and looks quite good. There is very little playability with this set, you can hide some jewels beneath a portion of the desert. That's pretty much it.
You recieve four Mini-Figures in this set, one of which is a bit of a cop out really on LEGO's part, instead of giving us four unique characters from the PoP film we get one standard LEGO Skeleton.

Prince Dastan is the same Mini-Fig found in just about all of the PoP sets, this time around however he has his horse, which really bumps up the value on the set as the horse in question has a unique body printing and a light blue/teal saddle.

The Hassassins are, according to the Mini-Fig browser, called Gahzab and Setam, Gahzab wields a large double-bladed battleaxe built like the Dwarve axes from the Fantasy Era Castle sets. He has a double-sided torso print resembling the armor he wears in the film, his head print is also quite unique, with a large brown patch covering one eye. As well as a beard and mustache and grim look, plus a few red lines to represent scars from previous battles.

Setam also has a double-sided torso print, the back showing his armor the front featuring his armor and six daggers, or bladed throwing weapons attached to the front. He also wears a nice new spiked shoulder piece and carries two triple-bladed claw weapons. (The set includes an extra one, giving you three of this unique new Mini-Fig weapon.) His facial print also has a few red scars, a much thicker beard and mustache. Both Hassassins include the new turban hat piece as well in black.

Overall, as far as Battle Packs go in Licensed Themes the Desert Attack is a very good bargain for your dollar, it includes three unique Mini-Figures and a horse, a red snake and black scorpion for your dangerous animal collection and throws in some great desert themed pieces. Plus two extra spears in a darker brown tone than we're used to seeing. My only complaint with the set is that instead of including a fourth PoP character to help Dastan against the Hassassins they cheap out and give us a tried and tired Skeleton Mini-Fig.

",TRUE,4,3,3,3,4

Sauron_Bauglir,"2012-05-23T22:06:01.923Z","A Good Little Set for Prince of Persia","

This is a fine little set to start off your Prince of Persia collection. Below are the Pros and Cons:

• This Dastan is better than in other sets, as he has a horse.
  • The Assassin with an axe is epic!
  • Lots of brilliant little parts! That is
column3:
the strongest point of the set.
  • Nice little desert scenery.
  • The gems, spears, scorpion and snake are very useful.
  • Nice skeleton.

column1:
• Way too overpriced.
  • The other Assassin is a bit boring.
  • Quite small.

Overall, this set is expensive but good. It is a brilliant way to start off your Prince of Persia collection. It will also fit in with Lego Castle and possibly Lego Lord of the Rings.

",TRUE,4,5,3,3,3
